Visualization Critique (Assignment 0)

A visualization that I like:

I like this one from the CDC, because it is informative and looks clean and pretty, even at a glance. The colors correspond to how dense COVID cases are in each state and they make sense. They go from very light yellow up to a dark autumn red. Based off of my natural intuition, I was able to immediately understand, albeit generally, which states have more cases per 100,000 people. A quick look at the legend helps me see exactly how dense the cases are. On the actual website, hovering the cursor over each state provides even more information, such as exact numbers, which is very helpful.

A visualization that I don't like:

I don't like this one from NBC, because it is hectic and at a glance, the reader can't even begin to make out what it is trying to convey - bad storytelling. Looking at it more closely, I am able to see that it is trying to show the change in the makeup of the US population over time (rather badly - the time intervals are too far apart and much too infrequent, with only 3 points for 100 years?!). It should be a stacked line chart with more data points, not some colorful blob of color in the shape of the US. Its shape makes it look like it is related to a map of some sort, like maybe the air currents over North America (with the red being warm air maybe?). Additionally, the percentages don't even add up correctly to 100%. Missing data? No axis labels? This one overall is a mess.

Simple redesign of the previous visualization:

In my redesign, I cleaned up the plot and simplified everything so it looks cleaner. I made each race/ethnicity its own line, each with different colors to display the trends more clearly. Overall, it's a very simple plot with not much to it, but is much easier to absorb and understand. I would add more data points, because 50 years is a pretty large gap between each point (not to mention that there are only three points for each).

Fixes to problems I mentioned earlier:

  1. All percentages add to a total of 100 (assumed a few values for the sake of completeness).
  2. Plot type better suited for the data (stacked lines).
  3. No weird/unnecessary plot shape.
  4. Cleaner, more easily noticeable trends.
  5. Cleaner looking legend.
  6. Added X and Y axis labels.
  7. Using Plot.ly in Jupyter Lab, plot is interactable. Hovering over lines shows values, as displayed in screenshots above.
